qas.question: What is another name for up-peak mode?
Generally, up-peak mode takes place during what times of the day?
What are the reasons for up-peak mode early in the day?

answers.text: people arrive for work or at the conclusion of a lunch-time period

qas.question: For what reasons are elevators routed one-by-one?

answers.text: when they reach a pre-determined passenger load, or when they have had their doors opened for a certain period of time

qas.question: Why is a "this car leaving next" sign used?

answers.text: to encourage passengers to make maximum use of the available elevator system capacity

context: During up-peak mode (also called <a0_0>moderate incoming traffic<a0_0/>), elevator cars in a group are recalled to the lobby to provide expeditious service to passengers arriving at the building, <a1_0>most typically in the morning<a1_0/> as <a2_0>people arrive for work or at the conclusion of a lunch-time period<a2_0/>. Elevators are dispatched one-by-one <a3_0>when they reach a pre-determined passenger load, or when they have had their doors opened for a certain period of time<a3_0/>. The next elevator to be dispatched usually has its hall lantern or a "this car leaving next" sign illuminated <a4_0>to encourage passengers to make maximum use of the available elevator system capacity<a4_0/>. Some elevator banks are programmed so that at least one car will always return to the lobby floor and park whenever it becomes free.
